subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Yes. (So happy, in fact, that I m one of the designers of such a language.) The meaning of the private modifier on an identifier is use this at your own
messageBody:
On Saturday 03 September 2005 10:06, Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Let me ask you this. How would you feel about making "private" just a
> suggestion? i.e. why not allow anyone to invoke any private method from
> any class they want to? Of course, they would know when doing this that
> they were doing something skanky. Would you be happy with such a
> language?

Yes. (So happy, in fact, that I'm one of the designers of such a
language.) The meaning of the "private" modifier on an identifier
is "use this at your own risk; we reserve the right to remove, rename,
change the semantics of, or otherwise screw you over if you do so".

We'd expect an IDE for this language to allow tighter controls to
be put on its use, of course; and "private" is just a special, built-in,
case of visibility facets, of which you can have as many as you
choose.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
Almost all predictions about life in 2015 are wrong in some fundamental
respect.
